title: A Carom Shot of Life
sub_head: Gwendolyn Brooks’s ‘We Real Cool’ uses enjambment to create a poem that’s masterly in its syncopated concision.
body: When I was a kid, growing up in Detroit, my friends and I embraced a verb now perhaps fallen out of favor: leg. It sounded adult and vaguely martial, or cinematic, or at least wiseguyish, and was most commonly employed in the imperative: Leg it. Meaning, Get moving, get walking, get your butt over here.
